title: Digital Revolution
text:
The Digital Revolution (also known as the Third Industrial Revolution) is the shift from <a href="machine">mechanical</a> and <a href="Analogue%20electronics">analogue electronic</a> <a href="technology">technology</a> to <a href="digital%20electronics">digital electronics</a> which began in the latter half of the 20th century, with the adoption and proliferation of digital computers and digital record-keeping, that continues to the present day. Implicitly, the term also refers to the sweeping changes brought about by digital <a href="computing">computing</a> and <a href="communication">communication</a> <a href="technology">technologies</a> during this period. From analogous to the <a href="Neolithic%20Revolution">Agricultural Revolution</a> and <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>, the Digital Revolution marked the beginning of the <a href="Information%20Age">Information Age</a>.
Central to this revolution is the <a href="mass%20production">mass production</a> and widespread use of <a href="digital%20logic">digital logic</a>, <a href="MOSFET">MOSFET</a>s (MOS <a href="transistor">transistor</a>s), <a href="integrated%20circuit">integrated circuit</a> (IC) chips, and their derived technologies, including <a href="computer">computer</a>s, <a href="microprocessor">microprocessor</a>s, digital <a href="cellular%20phone">cellular phone</a>s, and the <a href="Internet">Internet</a>. These technological innovations have transformed traditional production and business techniques.
History.
Brief history.
The <a href="Second%20Industrial%20Revolution">underlying technology</a> was invented in the later quarter of the 19th century, including <a href="Babbage">Babbage</a>'s <a href="Analytical%20Engine">Analytical Engine</a> and the <a href="telegraph">telegraph</a>. <a href="Data%20transmission">Digital communication</a> became economical for widespread adoption after the invention of the <a href="personal%20computer">personal computer</a>. <a href="Claude%20Elwood%20Shannon">Claude Shannon</a>, a Bell Labs mathematician, is credited for having laid out the foundations of <a href="Digitization">digitalization i</a>n his pioneering 1948 article, "A Mathematical Theory of Communication". The digital revolution converted technology from analog format to digital format. By doing this, it became possible to make copies that were identical to the original. In digital communications, for example, repeating hardware was able to amplify the <a href="digital%20signal">digital signal</a> and pass it on with no loss of information in the signal. Of equal importance to the revolution was the ability to easily move the digital information between media, and to access or distribute it remotely.
The turning point of the revolution was the change from analogue to digitally recorded music. During the 1980s the digital format of optical <a href="compact%20disc">compact disc</a>s gradually replaced <a href="analog%20electronics">analog</a> formats, such as <a href="vinyl%20records">vinyl records</a> and <a href="Compact%20Cassette">cassette tapes</a>, as the popular medium of choice.
1947–1969: Origins.
In 1947, the first working <a href="transistor">transistor</a>, the <a href="germanium">germanium</a>-based <a href="point-contact%20transistor">point-contact transistor</a>, was invented by <a href="John%20Bardeen">John Bardeen</a> and <a href="Walter%20Houser%20Brattain">Walter Houser Brattain</a> while working under <a href="William%20Shockley">William Shockley</a> at <a href="Bell%20Labs">Bell Labs</a>. This led the way to more advanced <a href="digital%20computers">digital computers</a>. From the late 1940s, universities, military, and businesses developed <a href="computer">computer</a> systems to digitally replicate and automate previously manually performed mathematical calculations, with the <a href="LEO%20%28computer%29">LEO</a> being the first commercially available general-purpose computer.
Other important technological developments included the invention of the monolithic <a href="integrated%20circuit">integrated circuit</a> chip by <a href="Robert%20Noyce">Robert Noyce</a> at <a href="Fairchild%20Semiconductor">Fairchild Semiconductor</a> in 1959 (made possible by the <a href="planar%20process">planar process</a> developed by <a href="Jean%20Hoerni">Jean Hoerni</a>), the first successful <a href="metal-oxide-semiconductor%20field-effect%20transistor">metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistor</a> (MOSFET, or MOS transistor) by <a href="Mohamed%20Atalla">Mohamed Atalla</a> and <a href="Dawon%20Kahng">Dawon Kahng</a> at Bell Labs in 1959, and the development of the <a href="complementary%20MOS">complementary MOS</a> (CMOS) process by <a href="Frank%20Wanlass">Frank Wanlass</a> and <a href="Chih-Tang%20Sah">Chih-Tang Sah</a> at Fairchild in 1963.
Following the development of <a href="MOS%20integrated%20circuit">MOS integrated circuit</a> chips in the early 1960s, MOS chips reached higher <a href="transistor%20density">transistor density</a> and lower manufacturing costs than <a href="bipolar%20junction%20transistor">bipolar</a> integrated circuits by 1964. MOS chips further increased in complexity at a rate predicted by <a href="Moore%27s%20law">Moore's law</a>, leading to <a href="large-scale%20integration">large-scale integration</a> (LSI) with hundreds of transistors on a single MOS chip by the late 1960s. The application of MOS LSI chips to <a href="computing">computing</a> was the basis for the first <a href="microprocessors">microprocessors</a>, as engineers began recognizing that a complete <a href="computer%20processor">computer processor</a> could be contained on a single MOS LSI chip. In 1968, Fairchild engineer <a href="Federico%20Faggin">Federico Faggin</a> improved MOS technology with his development of the <a href="silicon-gate">silicon-gate</a> MOS chip, which he later used to develop the <a href="Intel%204004">Intel 4004</a>, the first single-chip microprocessor. It was released by <a href="Intel">Intel</a> in 1971, and laid the foundations for the <a href="microcomputer%20revolution">microcomputer revolution</a> that began in the 1970s.
MOS technology also led to the development of semiconductor <a href="image%20sensors">image sensors</a> suitable for <a href="digital%20cameras">digital cameras</a>. The first such image sensor was the <a href="charge-coupled%20device">charge-coupled device</a>, developed by <a href="Willard%20S.%20Boyle">Willard S. Boyle</a> and <a href="George%20E.%20Smith">George E. Smith</a> at Bell Labs in 1969, based on <a href="MOS%20capacitor">MOS capacitor</a> technology.
1969–1989: Invention of the Internet, rise of home computers.
The public was first introduced to the concepts that led to the <a href="Internet">Internet</a> when a message was sent over the <a href="ARPANET">ARPANET</a> in 1969. <a href="Packet%20switching">Packet switched</a> networks such as ARPANET, <a href="Donald%20Davies">Mark I</a>, <a href="CYCLADES">CYCLADES</a>, <a href="Merit%20Network">Merit Network</a>, <a href="Tymnet">Tymnet</a>, and <a href="Telenet">Telenet</a>, were developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s using a variety of <a href="Communications%20protocol">protocols</a>. The ARPANET in particular led to the development of protocols for <a href="internetworking">internetworking</a>, in which multiple separate networks could be joined together into a network of networks.
The <a href="Stewart%20Brand">Whole Earth</a> movement of the 1960s advocated the use of new technology.
In the 1970s, the <a href="home%20computer">home computer</a> was introduced, <a href="Time-sharing">time-sharing computers</a>, the <a href="video%20game%20console">video game console</a>, the first coin-op video games, and the <a href="golden%20age%20of%20arcade%20video%20games">golden age of arcade video games</a> began with <a href="Space%20Invaders">Space Invaders</a>. As digital technology proliferated, and the switch from analog to digital record keeping became the new standard in business, a relatively new job description was popularized, the <a href="data%20entry%20clerk">data entry clerk</a>. Culled from the ranks of secretaries and typists from earlier decades, the data entry clerk's job was to convert analog data (customer records, invoices, etc.) into digital data.
In developed nations, computers achieved semi-ubiquity during the 1980s as they made their way into schools, homes, business, and industry. <a href="Automated%20teller%20machines">Automated teller machines</a>, <a href="industrial%20robots">industrial robots</a>, <a href="CGI%20animation">CGI</a> in film and television, <a href="electronic%20music">electronic music</a>, <a href="bulletin%20board%20systems">bulletin board systems</a>, and video games all fueled what became the zeitgeist of the 1980s. Millions of people purchased home computers, making household names of early personal computer manufacturers such as Apple, Commodore, and Tandy. To this day the Commodore 64 is often cited as the best selling computer of all time, having sold 17 million units (by some accounts) between 1982 and 1994.
In 1984, the U.S. Census Bureau began collecting data on computer and Internet use in the United States; their first survey showed that 8.2% of all U.S. households owned a personal computer in 1984, and that households with children under the age of 18 were nearly twice as likely to own one at 15.3% (middle and upper middle class households were the most likely to own one, at 22.9%). By 1989, 15% of all U.S. households owned a computer, and nearly 30% of households with children under the age of 18 owned one. By the late 1980s, many businesses were dependent on computers and digital technology.
Motorola created the first mobile phone, <a href="Motorola%20DynaTac">Motorola DynaTac</a>, in 1983. However, this device used analog communication - digital cell phones were not sold commercially until 1991 when the <a href="2G">2G</a> network started to be opened in Finland to accommodate the unexpected demand for cell phones that was becoming apparent in the late 1980s.
"<a href="Compute%21">Compute!</a>" magazine predicted that <a href="CD-ROM">CD-ROM</a> would be the centerpiece of the revolution, with multiple household devices reading the discs.
The first true <a href="digital%20camera">digital camera</a> was created in 1988, and the first were marketed in December 1989 in Japan and in 1990 in the United States. By the mid-2000s, they had eclipsed traditional film in popularity.
<a href="Digital%20ink%20and%20paint">Digital ink</a> was also invented in the late 1980s. Disney's CAPS system (created 1988) was used for a scene in 1989's "<a href="The%20Little%20Mermaid%20%281989%20film%29">The Little Mermaid</a>" and for all their animation films between 1990's "<a href="The%20Rescuers%20Down%20Under">The Rescuers Down Under</a>" and 2004's "<a href="Home%20on%20the%20Range%20%282004%20film%29">Home on the Range</a>".
1989–2005: Invention of the World Wide Web, mainstreaming of the Internet, Web 1.0.
<a href="Tim%20Berners-Lee">Tim Berners-Lee</a> invented the <a href="World%20Wide%20Web">World Wide Web</a> in 1989.
The first public digital <a href="HDTV">HDTV</a> broadcast was of the <a href="1990%20World%20Cup">1990 World Cup</a> that June; it was played in 10 theaters in Spain and Italy. However, HDTV did not become a standard until the mid-2000s outside Japan.
The <a href="World%20Wide%20Web">World Wide Web</a> became publicly accessible in 1991, which had been available only to government and universities. In 1993 <a href="Marc%20Andreessen">Marc Andreessen</a> and <a href="Eric%20Bina">Eric Bina</a> introduced <a href="Mosaic%20%28web%20browser%29">Mosaic</a>, the first web browser capable of displaying inline images and the basis for later browsers such as Netscape Navigator and Internet Explorer. <a href="Stanford%20Federal%20Credit%20Union">Stanford Federal Credit Union</a> was the first <a href="financial%20institution">financial institution</a> to offer online internet banking services to all of its members in October 1994. In 1996 <a href="OP%20Financial%20Group">OP Financial Group</a>, also a <a href="cooperative%20bank">cooperative bank</a>, became the second online bank in the world and the first in Europe. The <a href="Internet">Internet</a> expanded quickly, and by 1996, it was part of <a href="mass%20culture">mass culture</a> and many businesses listed websites in their ads. By 1999, almost every country had a connection, and nearly half of <a href="United%20States">Americans</a> and people in several other countries used the <a href="Internet">Internet</a> on a regular basis. However throughout the 1990s, "getting online" entailed complicated configuration, and <a href="dial-up">dial-up</a> was the only connection type affordable by individual users; the present day mass <a href="Internet%20culture">Internet culture</a> was not possible.
In 1989, about 15% of all households in the United States owned a personal computer.
For households with children, nearly 30% owned a computer in 1989, and in 2000, 65% owned one.
<a href="Cell%20phones">Cell phones</a> became as ubiquitous as computers by the early 2000s, with movie theaters beginning to show ads telling people to silence their phones. They also became <a href="smartphones">much more advanced</a> than phones of the 1990s, most of which only took calls or at most allowed for the playing of simple games.
<a href="Text%20messaging">Text messaging</a> existed in the 1990s but was not widely used until the early 2000s, when it became a cultural phenomenon.
The digital revolution became truly global in this time as well - after revolutionizing society in the <a href="developed%20world">developed world</a> in the 1990s, the digital revolution spread to the masses in the <a href="developing%20world">developing world</a> in the 2000s.
By 2000, a majority of U.S. households had at least one <a href="personal%20computer">personal computer</a> and <a href="internet%20access">internet access</a> the following year. In 2002, a majority of U.S. survey respondents reported having a <a href="mobile%20phone">mobile phone</a>.
2005–present: Web 2.0, social media, smartphones, digital TV.
In late 2005 the population of the <a href="Internet">Internet</a> reached 1 billion, and 3 billion people worldwide used cell phones by the end of the decade. <a href="HDTV">HDTV</a> became the standard television broadcasting format in many countries by the end of the decade. In September and December 2006 respectively, <a href="Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a> and the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> became the first countries to completely <a href="Digital%20terrestrial%20television%23Analogue%20to%20digital%20transition%20by%20countries">transition from analog to digital television</a>. In September 2007, a majority of U.S. survey respondents reported having <a href="Broadband%23Internet%20broadband">broadband internet</a> at home. According to estimates from the <a href="Nielsen%20Media%20Research">Nielsen Media Research</a>, approximately 45.7 million U.S. households in 2006 (or approximately 40 percent of approximately 114.4 million) owned a dedicated <a href="home%20video%20game%20console">home video game console</a>, and by 2015, 51 percent of U.S. households owned a dedicated home video game console according to an <a href="Entertainment%20Software%20Association">Entertainment Software Association</a> annual industry <a href="Memorandum">report</a>. By 2012, over 2 billion people used the Internet, twice the number using it in 2007. <a href="Cloud%20computing">Cloud computing</a> had entered the mainstream by the early 2010s. In January 2013, a majority of U.S. survey respondents reported owning a <a href="smartphone">smartphone</a>. By 2016, half of the world's population was connected and as of 2020, that number has risen to 67%.
Rise in digital technology use of computers, 1980–2020.
In the late 1980s, less than 1% of the world's technologically stored information was in digital format, while it was 94% in 2007, with more than 99% by 2014.
It is estimated that the world's capacity to store information has increased from 2.6 (optimally compressed) <a href="exabytes">exabytes</a> in 1986, to some 5,000 <a href="exabytes">exabytes</a> in 2014 (5 <a href="zettabytes">zettabytes</a>).
Converted technologies.
Conversion of below analog technologies to digital. (The decade indicated is the period when digital became dominant form.)
Decline or disappearance of below analog technologies:
Disappearance of other technologies also attributed to digital revolution. (Analog–digital classification doesn't apply to these.)
Improvements in digital technologies.
Technological basis.
The basic building block of the Digital Revolution is the <a href="metal-oxide-semiconductor%20field-effect%20transistor">metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistor</a> (MOSFET, or MOS transistor), which is the most widely manufactured device in history. It is the basis of every <a href="microprocessor">microprocessor</a>, <a href="memory%20chip">memory chip</a> and <a href="telecommunication%20circuit">telecommunication circuit</a> in commercial use. <a href="MOSFET%20scaling">MOSFET scaling</a> (rapid miniaturization of MOS transistors) has been largely responsible for enabling <a href="Moore%27s%20law">Moore's law</a>, which predicted that <a href="transistor%20count">transistor count</a>s would increase at an exponential pace.
Following the <a href="History%20of%20computing%20hardware">development of</a> the digital <a href="personal%20computer">personal computer</a>, <a href="MOSFET">MOS</a> microprocessors and memory chips, with their steadily increasing performance and storage, have enabled computer technology to be <a href="Embedded%20system">embedded</a> into a huge range of objects from <a href="Digital%20photography">cameras</a> to <a href="Digital%20audio%20player">personal music players</a>. Also important was the development of transmission technologies including <a href="computer%20network">computer network</a>ing, the <a href="Internet">Internet</a> and <a href="Digital%20audio%20broadcasting">digital broadcasting</a>. <a href="3G%20phones">3G phones</a>, whose social penetration grew exponentially in the 2000s, also played a very large role in the digital revolution as they simultaneously provide ubiquitous entertainment, communications, and online connectivity.
Socio-economic impact.
Positive aspects include greater interconnectedness, easier communication, and the exposure of information that in the past could have more easily been suppressed by <a href="totalitarian">totalitarian</a> regimes. <a href="Michio%20Kaku">Michio Kaku</a> wrote in his books <a href="Physics%20of%20the%20Future">Physics of the Future</a> that the failure of the <a href="1991%20Soviet%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat%20attempt">Soviet coup of 1991</a> was due largely to the existence of technology such as the <a href="fax%20machine">fax machine</a> and computers that exposed classified information.
The <a href="Revolutions%20of%202011">Revolutions of 2011</a> were enabled by social networking and smartphone technology; however these revolutions in hindsight largely failed to reach their goals as hardcore Islamist governments and in Syria a <a href="Syrian%20Civil%20War">civil war</a> have formed in the absence of the dictatorships that were toppled.
The economic impact of the digital revolution has been wide-ranging. Without the <a href="World%20Wide%20Web">World Wide Web</a> (WWW), for example, <a href="globalization">globalization</a> and <a href="outsourcing">outsourcing</a> would not be nearly as feasible as they are today. The digital revolution radically changed the way individuals and companies interact. Small regional companies were suddenly given access to much larger markets. Concepts such as <a href="Software%20as%20a%20service">on-demand</a> software services and manufacturing and rapidly dropping technology costs made possible innovations in all aspects of industry and everyday life.
After initial concerns of an IT <a href="productivity%20paradox">productivity paradox</a>, evidence is mounting that digital technologies have significantly increased the productivity and performance of businesses.
The Digital transformation allowed technology to continuously adapt which resulted in a boost in the economy with an increase of productivity. With the increase of technical advances, digital revolution has created a demand for new job skills. Economically, retailers, trucking companies and banks have transitioned into digital format. In addition, the introduction of cryptocurrency like Bitcoin creates faster and secure transactions.
Negative effects include <a href="information%20overload">information overload</a>, Internet predators, forms of social isolation, and media saturation. In a poll of prominent members of the national news media, 65 percent said the Internet is hurting journalism more than it is helping by allowing anyone no matter how amateur and unskilled to become a journalist; causing information to be muddier and the rise of <a href="conspiracy%20theory">conspiracy theory</a> in a way it didn't exist in the past.
In some cases, company employees' pervasive use of portable digital devices and work related computers for personal use—email, instant messaging, computer games—were often found to, or perceived to, reduce those companies' productivity. Personal computing and other non-work related digital activities in the workplace thus helped lead to stronger forms of privacy invasion, such as keystroke recording and information filtering applications (<a href="spyware">spyware</a> and <a href="content-control%20software">content-control software</a>).
Information sharing and privacy.
<a href="Privacy">Privacy</a> in general became a concern during the digital revolution. The ability to store and utilize such large amounts of diverse information opened possibilities for tracking of individual activities and interests. <a href="Libertarianism">Libertarians</a> and privacy rights advocates feared the possibility of an <a href="Orwellian">Orwellian</a> future where centralized power structures control the populace via automatic surveillance and monitoring of personal information in such programs as the CIA's <a href="Information%20Awareness%20Office">Information Awareness Office</a>. Consumer and labor advocates opposed the ability to direct market to individuals, discriminate in hiring and lending decisions, invasively monitor employee behavior and communications and generally profit from involuntarily shared personal information.
The <a href="Internet">Internet</a>, especially the <a href="WWW">WWW</a> in the 1990s, opened whole new avenues for communication and information sharing. The ability to easily and rapidly share information on a global scale brought with it a whole new level of <a href="freedom%20of%20speech">freedom of speech</a>. Individuals and organizations were suddenly given the ability to publish on any topic, to a global audience, at a negligible cost, particularly in comparison to any previous communication technology.
Large cooperative projects could be endeavored (e.g. <a href="Open-source%20software">Open-source software</a> projects, <a href="SETI%40home">SETI@home</a>). Communities of like-minded individuals were formed (e.g. <a href="MySpace">MySpace</a>, <a href="Tribe.net">Tribe.net</a>). Small regional companies were suddenly given access to a larger marketplace.
In other cases, special interest groups as well as social and religious institutions found much of the content objectionable, even dangerous. Many parents and religious organizations, especially in the United States, became alarmed by <a href="pornography">pornography</a> being more readily available to minors. In other circumstances the proliferation of information on such topics as child pornography, building bombs, committing acts of terrorism, and other violent activities were alarming to many different groups of people. Such concerns contributed to arguments for censorship and regulation on the WWW.
Copyright and trademark issues.
<a href="Copyright">Copyright</a> and <a href="trademark">trademark</a> issues also found new life in the digital revolution. The widespread ability of consumers to produce and distribute exact reproductions of protected works dramatically changed the intellectual property landscape, especially in the music, film, and television industries.
The digital revolution, especially regarding privacy, copyright, censorship and information sharing, remains a controversial topic. As the digital revolution progresses it remains unclear to what extent society has been impacted and will be altered in the future.
With the advancement of digital technology, copyright infringements will become difficult to detect. They will occur more frequently, will be difficult to prove and the public will continue to find loopholes around the law. Digital recorders for example, can be used personally and private use making the distributions of copywritten material discreet.
Concerns.
While there have been huge benefits to society from the digital revolution, especially in terms of the accessibility of information, there are a number of concerns. Expanded powers of communication and information sharing, increased capabilities for existing technologies, and the advent of <a href="Emerging%20technologies">new technology</a> brought with it many potential opportunities for exploitation. The digital revolution helped usher in a new age of <a href="mass%20surveillance">mass surveillance</a>, generating a range of new <a href="civil%20rights">civil</a> and <a href="human%20rights">human rights</a> issues. Reliability of data became an issue as information could easily be replicated, but not easily verified. For example, the introduction of Cryptocurrency, opens possibility for illegal trade, such as the sale of drugs, guns and black market transaction. The digital revolution made it possible to store and track facts, articles, statistics, as well as minutiae hitherto unfeasible.
From the perspective of the <a href="historian">historian</a>, a large part of human history is known through physical objects from the past that have been found or preserved, particularly in written documents. Digital records are easy to create but also easy to delete and modify. Changes in <a href="File%20format">storage formats</a> can make recovery of data difficult or near impossible, as can the storage of information on obsolete media for which reproduction equipment is unavailable, and even identifying what such data is and whether it is of interest can be near impossible if it is no longer easily readable, or if there is a large number of such files to identify. Information passed off as authentic research or study must be scrutinized and verified.
These problems are further compounded by the use of <a href="digital%20rights%20management">digital rights management</a> and other <a href="copy%20prevention">copy prevention</a> technologies which, being designed to only allow the data to be read on specific machines, may well make future <a href="data%20recovery">data recovery</a> impossible. The <a href="Voyager%20Golden%20Record">Voyager Golden Record</a>, which is intended to be read by an intelligent <a href="extraterrestrial%20life">extraterrestrial</a> (perhaps a suitable parallel to a human from the distant future), is recorded in <a href="analog%20%28signal%29">analog</a> rather than <a href="Digital%20data">digital format</a> specifically for easy interpretation and analysis.
Implications.
The shift to digitization in the contemporary media world has created implications for traditional mass media products. With more technology advances, the more converged the realm of mass media will become with less need for traditional communication technologies. For example, the Internet has transformed many communication norms, creating more efficiency not only for individuals but also for businesses. However, <a href="Denis%20McQuail">McQuail</a> suggests traditional media have also benefited greatly from new media, allowing more effective and efficient resources available.
Environmental impact.
The digital technology industry is one of the least sustainable and most <a href="Human%20impact%20on%20the%20environment%23Technology%20impacts">environmentally damaging</a> sectors in the modern world, due to its inextricable link to the <a href="electronics%20industry">electronics industry</a> and the <a href="Electronic%20waste">waste</a> produced by it. Digitization facilitates the mass propagation of data, which requires the existence of <a href="Data%20center">data centers</a> for processing and storage. These centers consume significant amounts of the electricity supply of a host country.
